prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong in this situation. The scenario is about a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the author who handles most of the household chores and child care. The husband works from home a few days a week, mostly on conference calls. The author suggests moving to the basement for less disruption, but he prefers the bedroom because of the view. Now, the author can't do basic things like shower or nap when he's working from the bedroom. She works from home too and does most of the chores and kids. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom but would if he's in the basement. They're arguing about who's the asshole.

First, I need to figure out if the author is in the wrong. The husband chose not to take the option that minimizes disruption. The author is explaining that his choice affects her ability to function. The husband is expecting her to keep him undisturbed, but she's saying that's difficult given the kids and chores. The key points here are about mutual consideration and practicality.

The husband's choice to work in the bedroom seems self-centered if he's aware it causes issues. The author is trying to balance work and household responsibilities. She's not saying she'll be completely quiet, but she's making an effort by suggesting the basement. The husband's refusal might be the root of the problem. The author isn't at fault for not being able to control the kids or the household when he's in a space she can't avoid. The fact that there's a viable alternative (basement) that he's ignoring suggests he's the one not compromising. So, the answer would be B, the author isn't in the wrong.
